relations.content: Indiana University Center for the Study of History and Memory

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <did xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9">
                  <repository>
                     <corpname>Indiana University Center for the Study of History and Memory</corpname>
                     <address>
                        <addressline>Indiana University</addressline>
                        <addressline>400 North Sunrise Drive</addressline>
                        <addressline>Weatherly Hall North, Room 122</addressline>
                        <addressline>Bloomington, IN 47405</addressline>
                        <addressline>Phone: 812/855-2856</addressline>
                        <addressline>Fax: 812/855-0002</addressline>
                        <addressline>E-mail: ohrc@indiana.edu</addressline>
                     </address>
                     <extref>http://www.indiana.edu/~cshm</extref>
                  </repository>
                  <origination>
                     <corpname>Indiana University Center for the
                    Study of History and Memory</corpname>
                  </origination>
                  <unittitle>IU School of Music</unittitle>
                  <unitdate>1983</unitdate>
                  <unitid>ohrc071</unitid>
                  <physdesc>
                     <extent>1 interview</extent>. <extent>Audiotapes, transcripts, and collateral
                    materials</extent>. </physdesc>
                  <physloc>Interviews are housed in Weatherly Hall North, Room
                122. Copies are also housed at the Indiana University Archives in Herman B Wells
                Library E460. For other locations housing the interviews from this project, please
                contact the Center for the Study of History and Memory office.</physloc>
                  <langmaterial>Materials are in <language>English</language>
                  </langmaterial>
                  <abstract>Wilfred C. Bain, dean of the School of Music from 1947 to 1973, discusses his career
                as an administrator in various colleges. He focuses on his time at the Indiana
                University School of Music, discussing the policies he feels made the school the
                success it is today. He also discusses his theories and philosophies behind music
                education and how he has tried to implement them at the School of Music.</abstract>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: IU School of Music 1983
resource.abstract: Wilfred C. Bain, dean of the School of Music from 1947 to 1973, discusses his career                as an administrator in various colleges. He focuses on his time at the Indiana                University School of Music, discussing the policies he feels made the school the                success it is today. He also discusses his theories and philosophies behind music                education and how he has tried to implement them at the School of Music.
resource.extent: 1 interview; Audiotapes, transcripts, and collateral                    materials

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <did xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9">
                  <unittitle>Correspondence from the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation Collection
		  <unitdate>1894-1953</unitdate>
                     <unitdate>(bulk 1920-1953)</unitdate>
                  </unittitle>
                  <unitid>ML29j.C66</unitid>
                  <origination>
                     <persname>Coolidge, Elizabeth Sprague, 1864-1953</persname>
                  </origination>
                  <physdesc>
                     <extent>around 56,680 items</extent>
                     <extent>109 containers</extent>
                     <extent>48.50 linear feet</extent>
                  </physdesc>
                  <langmaterial>Collection material in
		<language>English</language>
                  </langmaterial>
                  <repository>
                     <corpname>
                        <subarea>Music Division</subarea> Library of
			 Congress</corpname>
                     <address>
                        <addressline>Washington, D.C.</addressline>
                     </address>
                  </repository>
                  <abstract>Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge was a composer, pianist, and patron of music. In 1925, she created the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation at the Library of Congress in support of chamber music. The collection contains Coolidge's correspondence to and from many of the prominent musical artists of the first half of the twentieth century. Extensive correspondence between Coolidge and Library of Congress librarians and administrators is also included. The remaining materials in the collection, including photographs, scrapbooks, business papers, programs, publicity materials, iconography, realia, and clippings, are available for research and will be incorporated into the finding aid at a later date. Music manuscripts of works commissioned by Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge or the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation in the Library of Congress comprise a substantial portion of the collection and are cataloged individually.</abstract>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Correspondence from the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation Collection 1894-1953 (bulk 1920-1953)
resource.abstract: Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge was a composer, pianist, and patron of music. In 1925, she created the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation at the Library of Congress in support of chamber music. The collection contains Coolidge's correspondence to and from many of the prominent musical artists of the first half of the twentieth century. Extensive correspondence between Coolidge and Library of Congress librarians and administrators is also included. The remaining materials in the collection, including photographs, scrapbooks, business papers, programs, publicity materials, iconography, realia, and clippings, are available for research and will be incorporated into the finding aid at a later date. Music manuscripts of works commissioned by Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge or the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation in the Library of Congress comprise a substantial portion of the collection and are cataloged individually.
resource.displayEntry: Correspondence from the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation Collection, 1894-1953, (bulk 1920-1953)

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <did xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9">
                  <unittitle>Ross Lee Finney collection : sound and video recordings</unittitle>
                  <unitdate>1938-1986</unitdate>
                  <unitid>*L (Special) 98-16</unitid>
                  <unitid>20475</unitid>
                  <origination>
                     <persname>Finney, Ross Lee, 1906-1997</persname>
                  </origination>
                  <repository>
                     <corpname>The New York Public Library. Rodgers and Hammerstein Archives of Recorded Sound.</corpname>
                     <address>
                        <addressline>New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Center</addressline>
                        <addressline>40 Lincoln Center Plaza, New York, NY 10023-7498</addressline>
                     </address>
                  </repository>
                  <physdesc>137 sound recordings.</physdesc>
                  <abstract>Ross Lee Finney (1906-1997) was an American composer and teacher. Born in Wells, MN, he studied at the University of Minnesota with Donald Ferguson, in Paris with Nadia Boulanger,and at Harvard with Edward Burlingame Hill. He also studied with Roger Sessions (1935), Alban Berg (1931-1932), and Gian Francesco Malipiero (1937). Finney taught at Smith College (1929-49) ; Mt. Holyoke College (1938-40) ; Hartt School of Music (1941-42), and Amherst College (1946-1947). He was a visiting lecturer at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor (1948-1949), and later became a professor there (1949-73). During his time at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, Finney served as chairman of the composition department, and established an electronic music laboratory.</abstract>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Ross Lee Finney collection : sound and video recordings 1938-1986
resource.abstract: Ross Lee Finney (1906-1997) was an American composer and teacher. Born in Wells, MN, he studied at the University of Minnesota with Donald Ferguson, in Paris with Nadia Boulanger,and at Harvard with Edward Burlingame Hill. He also studied with Roger Sessions (1935), Alban Berg (1931-1932), and Gian Francesco Malipiero (1937). Finney taught at Smith College (1929-49) ; Mt. Holyoke College (1938-40) ; Hartt School of Music (1941-42), and Amherst College (1946-1947). He was a visiting lecturer at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor (1948-1949), and later became a professor there (1949-73). During his time at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, Finney served as chairman of the composition department, and established an electronic music laboratory.
resource.displayEntry: Ross Lee Finney collection : sound and video recordings, 1938-1986
